## To streamline our development workflow we can use a CLI utility called nodemon to watch for changes to files in our project and restart the node process when a change event is detected.

nodemon is a Node package, so we can install it with NPM.

## Installing Packages Globally

In this case we want to install nodemon as a utility for use anywhere on our machine, so we install it globally (as opposed to as a dependency of the project we're working).

```bash
npm install nodemon --global
```

![npm install nodemon global](data:image/png;base64,)

> [!CAUTION]
> If you run into permissions errors with the above, you'll need to run it with elevated permissions.
>
> - On Windows, open PowerShell, but run it as administrator by right-clicking on PowerShell in your start menu and selecting "Run as Administrator".
> - On Mac you don't need to change terminals, you just need to prefix the command with `sudo`.

_Note: When we install dependencies globally they do not make any changes to the package dependencies listed in `package.json`_

## Running and Watching Hello Node for Changes

In your terminal, in the root directory of your project, run:

```bash
nodemon app.js
```

![nodemon appjs running](data:image/png;base64,)

Nodemon ran `node app.js` and is now monitoring for changes.

Leave your terminal open, edit the `console.log` statement in `app.js`, then save.

![nodemon restart output](data:image/png;base64,)

### **Installing Packages As Dev Dependencies**

For the upcoming Assignment 01 we will need to install nodemon as a dev dependency of the project anyways.

To do so you will need to run:

```bash
npm install nodemon --save-dev
```

After running the above you should see nodemon listed as a dev dependency in `package.json`

![package json devDependencies](data:image/png;base64,)

You will also see a `node_modules` directory and `package-lock.json` added to your project.

> [!TIP]
> If you don't already have one, now would be the best time to add a `.gitignore` file that excludes `node_modules` from being tracked by git.

### **Using nodemon via npm**

If we want to run your program via nodemon using npm, edit your `package.json` as follows:

```json
"scripts": {
  "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1",
  "dev": "nodemon app"
},
```

With that in place, we can run the following from the command line to start our program and have it automatically restart when changes are detected:

```bash
npm run dev
```
